If you think of all the suffering people and wish to save them, why do you say you have no desires?
The Buddha asked the bodhisattvas:
When you went to the buddhas in the ten directions to ask about the sutras, have you forgotten them now?
The bodhisattvas replied:
The sutras I asked about, I all know and have not forgotten.
The Buddha asked the bodhisattvas:
You know the sutras spoken by the buddhas in the ten directions, have you transmitted them to teach others?
The bodhisattvas said:
Yes!
I teach the sutras to others every day.
The Buddha said:
If you teach the sutras to others, do you wish for others to understand?
The bodhisattvas said:
Yes!
I wish for others to understand.
The Buddha said:
If you teach the sutras to others, wishing for others to understand, then you have desires. Why do you say you have no desires?
The Buddha further asked the bodhisattvas:
If you explain the sutras to people, do you teach them to give or not?
The bodhisattvas said:
Yes!
We teach people to give. The Buddha asked the bodhisattvas:
If you teach people to give, what do you use to give to the Buddha?
The bodhisattvas replied:
First, we want people to offer beautiful flowers.
The Buddha said:
You do not desire form, so why do you have people offer five-colored beautiful flowers that can be seen to the Buddha?
In this way, you have desire for form, so why do you say we do not desire form?
The Buddha further asked the bodhisattvas:
If you hear the sutras spoken by the Buddhas of the ten directions, can you hear them or not?
The bodhisattvas replied:
The Buddhas of the ten directions speak sutras for us and we can hear them. We are all delighted.
The Buddha said:
As you hear the sutras and are delighted, it is desire. Why do you say we have no desire?
The Buddha further asked the bodhisattvas:
Do you wish to teach people to burn incense for the Buddha?
The bodhisattvas replied to the Buddha:
We ourselves daily gather various flowers and famous incense to offer to the Buddha.
The Buddha said:
Just as you gather various flowers and incense, wishing to obtain a pleasing fragrance, and offer it to the Buddha.
The Buddha said:
If you wish to obtain fragrant flowers that are pleasing to the nose, such is desire. Why do you say there is no desire?
The Buddha further asked the bodhisattvas:
When you expound the sutra for people, do you wish to please the mouth?
The bodhisattvas said:
When we expound the sutra for people, we wish to distinguish and please the mouth, and wish to make people understand.
The Buddha said:
If you please the mouth for the sake of desire, why do you say there is no desire?
The Buddha further asked the bodhisattvas:
Do you wish to be fully endowed with the thirty-two marks that please the body?
The bodhisattvas said:
We only want to satisfy the body with the complete characteristics of hardship.
The Buddha said:
If satisfying the body is desire, why do you say you have no desire?
The bodhisattvas bowed their heads in shame.
The Buddha said:
In this way, the bodhisattvas still have no support.
The bodhisattvas bowed their heads and said:
We pray that the Buddha will have compassion on us and explain it for us.
The Buddha explained for them:

When practicing the bodhisattva path, if one practices meditation by counting the breath or relies on concentration, one should calculate the one hundred and eight faults. If they are extinguished, one should meditate; if they are not extinguished, one should not meditate.
The bodhisattvas asked the Buddha:
Meditation is for abandoning evil. If the one hundred and eight faults are extinguished, it is for abandoning evil. If they are not extinguished, it is not for abandoning evil.

If one arises from meditation, whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, if one preaches the sutras for others based on conditions, and if one can contemplate the myriad phenomena and avoid the one hundred and eight faults, and can prevent attachment and falling into offenses, this is called the practice of contemplation by a bodhisattva.
The bodhisattvas asked the Buddha:
The contemplation of the one hundred and eight faults, from where do they arise?
The Buddha told the bodhisattvas:

As for the contemplation of the one hundred and eight faults, in the mind of a bodhisattva, there are five aggregates and habits, which is a fault;ğŸ”½The mind turns into intention, and there are five aggregates and habits, which is a fault;

The intention turns into consciousness, and there are five aggregates and habits, which is a fault.ğŸ”½It turns into the eyes, and what the eyes see as good form has five aggregates and habits, which is a fault;
What the eyes see as middling form has five aggregates and habits, which is a fault;
The evil forms seen by the eyes have five aggregates and within them are habits, which is falling.

Turning to the ears, the good sounds heard by the ears have five aggregates and within them are habits, which is falling;ğŸ”½the sounds of the middle kind heard by the ears have five aggregates and within them are habits, which is falling;
the evil sounds heard by the ears have five aggregates and within them are habits, which is falling.

Turning to the nose, the good fragrances smelled by the nose have five aggregates and within them are habits, which is falling;ğŸ”½the fragrances of the middle kind smelled by the nose have five aggregates and within them are habits, which is falling;

the evil smells smelled by the nose have five aggregates and within them are habits, which is falling.ğŸ”½Turning to the mouth, the delicious flavors and good words obtained by the mouth have five aggregates and within them are habits, which is falling;
the flavors and words of the middle kind obtained by the mouth have five aggregates and within them are habits, which is falling;
The bad tastes and bad words obtained by the mouth have five aggregates and habits within them, which are called falling.
Transference enters the body. The good, fine, soft, and pleasant sensations obtained by the body have five aggregates and habits within them, which are called falling;
The medium, fine, soft, and pleasant sensations obtained by the body have five aggregates and habits within them, which are called falling;
The bad, coarse, hard, painful, and unpleasant sensations obtained by the body have five aggregates and habits within them, which are called falling;
These are the one hundred and eight falling practices.
The Buddha told the bodhisattvas:

Calculating the one hundred and eight falls, not knowing the offenses one has fallen into, suffering and pain will come later, and one will also not know shame. One says oneself that one can cut off the one hundred and eight falling practices.
The Buddha said:

This person is like a lustful and jealous woman who, after having sex, becomes pregnant. She does not know how much the fetus grows in her womb each day. The lustful and jealous woman continues to have sex until the tenth month, when the child is about to be born. Whether the child will turn or not, whether it will be born or not, the mother's abdomen aches and she feels ashamed and remorseful.

When the pain of childbirth arrives, the jealous woman's cries are heard up to the seventh heaven. After the child is born, the mother's pain subsides, and she thinks of having sex again. She no longer thinks of shame or pain, and continues to have sex as before. Such suffering is indescribable, and the jealous woman is also unable to realize her own pain.
The Buddha said:

When a bodhisattva practices the Way, he does not calculate the one hundred and eight falls. It is like a lustful and jealous woman who does not know herself the number of her offenses, nor is she disgusted with suffering, nor does she calculate her shame and guilt, nor does she know the suffering of the five paths of birth and death, nor does she know herself falling into the three evil paths, nor does she feel ashamed of her actions, saying 'I have fallen into the Way.'
Thus, she receives misfortune for herself life after life.
She herself feels ashamed of this, but there is no benefit. A disciple of the Way should study carefully.
All the bodhisattvas joyfully bowed and accepted the practice.
The Buddha said:
The bodhisattvas are still not yet enlightened in this way.
The bodhisattvas asked the Buddha:
Why is it that we are not yet enlightened?
The Buddha said:
It is because the bodhisattvas cannot calculate the one hundred and eight attachments.
The bodhisattvas asked the Buddha:
What is meant by calculating the one hundred and eight attachments?
The Buddha said:
The bodhisattva's practice of meditation cannot make a single thought or a single mind cease, but only sits and clings to the one hundred and eight [afflictions].
First, the bodhisattva's mind has thoughts that cannot be extinguished, which is craving. There are five aggregates within craving, and within them are habitual tendencies. This is called craving.
The mind turns into intention and cannot be extinguished, which is craving. There are five aggregates within craving, and within them are habitual tendencies. This is called craving.

Intention turns into consciousness and cannot be extinguished, which is craving. There are five aggregates within craving, and within them are habitual tendencies. This is called craving.ğŸ”½It turns into the eyes, and the eyes cannot extinguish what they see as good form, which is craving. There are five aggregates within craving, and within them are habitual tendencies. This is called craving;ğŸ”½the eyes cannot extinguish what they see as middling form, which is craving. There are five aggregates within craving, and within them are habitual tendencies. This is called craving;
the eyes cannot extinguish what they see as bad form, which is craving. There are five aggregates within craving, and within them are habitual tendencies. This is called craving.

Turning to the ears, the pleasant sounds heard by the ears cannot be eliminated, and there are five aggregates and habits in this love, which is called love;ğŸ”½The sounds of the middle heard by the ears cannot be eliminated, and there are five aggregates and habits in this love, which is called love;

The unpleasant sounds heard by the ears cannot be eliminated, and there are five aggregates and habits in this love, which is called love.ğŸ”½Turning to the nose, the pleasant scents smelled by the nose cannot be eliminated, and there are five aggregates and habits in this love, which is called love;
The scents of the middle smelled by the nose cannot be eliminated, and there are five aggregates and habits in this love, which is called love;
The unpleasant smells smelled by the nose cannot be eliminated, and there are five aggregates and habits in this love, which is called love.
Turning to the mouth, the delicious flavors and pleasant words obtained by the mouth cannot be eliminated, and there are five aggregates and habits in this love, which is called love;
The flavors and middling speech obtained by the mouth cannot be eliminated, and there are five aggregates and habits in the middle of desire, which is called craving.

The bad flavors and bad speech obtained by the mouth cannot be eliminated, and there are five aggregates and habits in the middle of desire, which is called craving.ğŸ”½Turning to the body, the fine and soft body sensations obtained by the body cannot be eliminated, and there are five aggregates and habits in the middle of desire, which is called craving;
The middling fine and soft sensations obtained by the body cannot be eliminated, and there are five aggregates and habits in the middle of desire, which is called craving;
The bad, coarse, hard, painful, and unpleasant body sensations obtained by the body cannot be eliminated, and there are five aggregates and habits in the middle of desire, which is called craving.
The Buddha said:
When practicing the Way, bodhisattvas do not calculate the elimination of the one hundred and eight cravings, and do not know by themselves the one hundred and eight cravings that lead to offenses.
It is like a newborn infant, from small to large, not knowing by themselves how much they increase each day.
The bodhisattva practices the Way but cannot be aware of the quantity of offenses, it is like this.

If the bodhisattva practices the Way and is aware of the one hundred and eight offenses that fall due to craving, he should then be ashamed of himself, he should then cut it off himself, he should then separate himself from it, he should then extinguish it himself, in this way, cutting off craving is in accordance with the bodhisattva.
The Buddha spoke like this, and all the bodhisattvas bowed their heads and accepted the practice.
The Buddha said:

The bodhisattva practices the Way and should calculate the one hundred and eight afflictions. If he practices the Way without calculating the one hundred and eight afflictions, it is not in accordance with the bodhisattva practice. Only by removing the afflictions is it in accordance with the bodhisattva practice.
The bodhisattvas asked the Buddha, saying:
How should the afflictions be removed?
The Buddha told the bodhisattvas, saying:

The bodhisattva should sit alone in one place and practice meditation, counting the breath, following it, stopping, contemplating, returning, and purifying. If he attains purity, it is for the removal of afflictions. If he is impure, it is for the non-removal of afflictions. In this way, when he arises from meditation, whether he is among people, he should practice calculation and cut off the afflictions.
The bodhisattvas asked the Buddha,
How should we calculate the removal of the stumps?
The Buddha said,
Practicing the Way without attaining a single-minded concentration is not the eradication of the stumps.
The Buddha said,
Those who do not attain a single-minded concentration, with thoughts in the mind, have the five aggregates and their habits, and thus give rise to the stumps.
Transference enters the mind, in the mind there are the five aggregates and their habits, and thus give rise to the stumps.
Transference enters consciousness, in consciousness there are the five aggregates and their habits, and thus give rise to the stumps.
Transference enters the eyes, the eyes see good forms and within them there are the five aggregates and their habits, and thus give rise to the stumps;
the eyes see forms in between and within them there are the five aggregates and their habits, and thus give rise to the stumps;
the eyes see bad forms and within them there are the five aggregates and their habits, and thus give rise to the stumps.
Transference enters the ears, the ears hear good sounds and within them there are the five aggregates and their habits, and thus give rise to the stumps;
Among the sounds heard by the ears, there are five aggregates and habits, which give rise to afflictions;
Among the bad sounds heard by the ears, there are five aggregates and habits, which give rise to afflictions.

Turning to the nose, the good scents smelled by the nose have five aggregates and habits, which give rise to afflictions;ğŸ”½The scents smelled by the nose have five aggregates and habits, which give rise to afflictions;
The bad smells smelled by the nose have five aggregates and habits, which give rise to afflictions.

Turning to the mouth, the delicious flavors and good words obtained by the mouth have five aggregates and habits, which give rise to afflictions;ğŸ”½The middling flavors and middling words obtained by the mouth have five aggregates and habits, which give rise to afflictions;
The bad flavors and bad words obtained by the mouth have five aggregates and habits, which give rise to afflictions.
Turning to the body, the fine, soft, and pleasing sensations obtained by the body have five aggregates and habits, which give rise to afflictions;
Among the subtle and soft things obtained by the body, there are five aggregates and habits, which give rise to afflictions;
Among the evil, coarse, hard, painful, and unbearable things obtained by the body, there are five aggregates and habits, which give rise to afflictions. In this way, the afflictions are not cut off.
The Buddha said:
If a bodhisattva practices the Way and says 'I do not have these afflictions,' this is arrogance.
Planting afflictions oneself, one is unable to liberate oneself, lacks wisdom, and cannot know the quantity of afflictions.
It is like the hair on the body. A person cannot count each strand and cannot know the quantity of hair.
Bodhisattvas who practice the Way are unable to remove their own afflictions and instead say 'I seek the Buddha Way and wish to liberate the ten directions.'
In this way, they are unable to liberate themselves, let alone liberate the ten directions.
Bodhisattvas who practice the Way and can remove afflictions are able to liberate the ten directions;
Those who do not remove afflictions are unable to liberate the ten directions.
The Buddha spoke thus, and all the bodhisattvas joyfully accepted and practiced it.
The Buddha said:
The bodhisattvas have not yet fully understood this.
The bodhisattvas bowed again and said:
We have not yet understood this. We pray that the Buddha will explain it for us.
The Buddha said:
Bodhisattvas have one hundred and eight offenses and consciousnesses that have not been extinguished. They should not be considered bodhisattvas.
The bodhisattvas asked the Buddha:
What are the one hundred and eight offenses and consciousnesses?

The Buddha said:ğŸ”½It means that when the mind of a bodhisattva thinks of an offense, there are five aggregates and habits within it, which form consciousness. This is called the consciousness of an offense.ğŸ”½It moves into the mind, and when the mind thinks of something again and again, it becomes an offense. There are five aggregates and habits within it, which form consciousness. This is called the consciousness of an offense.

It moves into consciousness, and when consciousness thinks of something and does not forget it, it becomes an offense. There are five aggregates and habits within it, which form consciousness. This is called the consciousness of an offense.
Turning to the eyes, the eyes see good forms as offenses, with five aggregates and habits within, which form consciousness, this is offense-forming consciousness;
the eyes see middling forms as offenses, with five aggregates and habits within, which form consciousness, this is offense-forming consciousness;
the eyes see bad forms as offenses, with five aggregates and habits within, which form consciousness, this is offense-forming consciousness.

Turning to the ears, the ears hear good sounds as offenses, with five aggregates and habits within, which form consciousness, this is offense-forming consciousness;ğŸ”½the ears hear middling sounds as offenses, with five aggregates and habits within, which form consciousness, this is offense-forming consciousness;
the ears hear bad sounds as offenses, with five aggregates and habits within, which form consciousness, this is offense-forming consciousness.
Turning to the nose, the nose smells good fragrances as offenses, with five aggregates and habits within, which form consciousness, this is offense-forming consciousness;
The fragrant smells perceived by the nose are sinful, with the five aggregates and habitual tendencies therein constituting consciousness, which is sinful consciousness;
The foul smells perceived by the nose are sinful, with the five aggregates and habitual tendencies therein constituting consciousness, which is sinful consciousness.

Transformed into the mouth, the delicious flavors and pleasant words obtained by the mouth are sinful, with the five aggregates and habitual tendencies therein constituting consciousness, which is sinful consciousness;ğŸ”½The middling flavors and middling words obtained by the mouth are sinful, with the five aggregates and habitual tendencies therein constituting consciousness, which is sinful consciousness;

The foul flavors and foul words obtained by the mouth are sinful, with the five aggregates and habitual tendencies therein constituting consciousness, which is sinful consciousness.ğŸ”½Transformed into the body, the fine, smooth, and pleasant sensations experienced by the body are sinful, with the five aggregates and habitual tendencies therein constituting consciousness, which is sinful consciousness;
The middling fine, smooth sensations experienced by the body are sinful, with the five aggregates and habitual tendencies therein constituting consciousness, which is sinful consciousness;

The evil, coarse, solid, painful, and unbearable body that one obtains is a sin. Within it there are five aggregates, and within it there are habitual tendencies that constitute consciousness. This is the consciousness of sin.
The Buddha asked the bodhisattvas:
Do you have these sins or not?
The bodhisattvas said:
We only have the five aggregates, and no sins.
The Buddha further asked the bodhisattvas:
What in the world causes people to have sins and not attain the Way?
The bodhisattvas replied to the Buddha:
People in the world all sit in greed and do not attain the Way.
The Buddha said:
Do people in the world who are greedy for birth and death have the habitual tendencies of the five aggregates or not?
The bodhisattvas said:
There are sins.
The Buddha asked the bodhisattvas:
If you uphold the view of the body and attain Buddhahood, you will still be subject to birth and death.
The bodhisattvas replied to the Buddha:
We will still be subject to birth and death, but we will not attain Buddhahood in this present body.
The Buddha asked the bodhisattvas:
How many more lifetimes will you have to go through before attaining Buddhahood?
The bodhisattvas replied to the Buddha:
We have not yet determined the number of our lifetimes.
The Buddha further asked the bodhisattvas:
Why is there no determination?
The bodhisattvas said:
We do not know the quantity of our merits and demerits.
For this reason, we do not know the determination.
The Buddha told the bodhisattvas:
In this way, what is the difference between you and the people of the world?
The bodhisattvas replied to the Buddha:
We can fly to the Buddha lands in the ten directions and we can understand what the Buddha says.
The Buddha said:
If you can fly to the Buddha lands in the ten directions and understand what the Buddhas in the ten directions say,
why don't you attain Buddhahood immediately? Why do you still have a determination for lifetimes?
The bodhisattvas replied to the Buddha:

We still have fundamental offenses that have not been exhausted, and therefore our fundamental vows and meritorious virtues are not yet complete. For this reason, we should not attain Buddhahood immediately.
The Buddha said:

You say that all people in the world have offenses only because of the habitual cycle of birth and death of the five skandhas. Now you should also have offenses due to the habitual cycle of birth and death.
Why do you tell me you have no offenses?
The bodhisattvas were all ashamed, bowed their heads, and accepted the teaching.
The Buddha said:
Although I have said this, the bodhisattvas still do not understand.
The bodhisattvas bowed their heads and said:
We pray that the Buddha will explain it for us again.
The Buddha said:
Bodhisattvas have one hundred and eight causes and conditions for being attached to suffering.
The bodhisattvas asked the Buddha:
What are the one hundred and eight causes and conditions for being attached to suffering?
The Buddha said:

When the mind of a bodhisattva has thoughts, it is a cause and condition for the arising of pain, within which there are five aggregates, within which there are habits, and one will sit in the cause and condition of the pain of birth and death.

Turning to the mind, when the mind has thoughts, it is a cause and condition for the arising of pain, within which there are five aggregates, within which there are habits, and one will sit in the cause and condition of the pain of birth and death.

Turning to consciousness, when consciousness has something it is conscious of, it is a cause and condition for the arising of pain, within which there are five aggregates, within which there are habits, and one will sit in the cause and condition of the pain of birth and death.

Turning to the eyes, when the eyes see good forms, it is a cause and condition for the arising of pain, within which there are five aggregates, within which there are habits, and one will sit in the cause and condition of the pain of birth and death;

when the eyes see middling forms, it is a cause and condition for the arising of pain, within which there are five aggregates, within which there are habits, and one will sit in the cause and condition of the pain of birth and death;

when the eyes see bad forms, it is a cause and condition for the arising of pain, within which there are five aggregates, within which there are habits, and one will sit in the cause and condition of the pain of birth and death.ğŸ”½

Turning to the ears, when the ears hear pleasant sounds, it becomes a cause for attachment to pain, within which there are five aggregates and within which there are habits, one will sit due to causes and conditions of birth and death;ğŸ”½When the ears hear neutral sounds, it becomes a cause for attachment to pain, within which there are five aggregates and within which there are habits, one will sit due to causes and conditions of birth and death;

When the ears hear unpleasant sounds, it becomes a cause for attachment to pain, within which there are five aggregates and within which there are habits, one will sit due to causes and conditions of birth and death.

Turning to the nose, when the nose smells pleasant fragrances, it becomes a cause for attachment to pain, within which there are five aggregates and within which there are habits, one will sit due to causes and conditions of birth and death;ğŸ”½When the nose smells neutral scents, it becomes a cause for attachment to pain, within which there are five aggregates and within which there are habits, one will sit due to causes and conditions of birth and death;

When the nose smells unpleasant odors, it becomes a cause for attachment to pain, within which there are five aggregates and within which there are habits, one will sit due to causes and conditions of birth and death.

Transference to the mouth: The delicious flavors and pleasant words obtained by the mouth become the cause and condition for attachment to pain, within which there are five aggregates and within which there is habit, one will sit due to the cause and condition of the pain of birth and death;ğŸ”½The middling flavors and middling words obtained by the mouth become the cause and condition for attachment to pain, within which there are five aggregates and within which there is habit, one will sit due to the cause and condition of the pain of birth and death;

The bad flavors and bad words obtained by the mouth become the cause and condition for pain, within which there are five aggregates and within which there is habit, one will sit due to the cause and condition of the pain of birth and death.ğŸ”½Transference to the body: The fine, soft, and pleasant sensations obtained by the body become the cause and condition for attachment to pain, within which there are five aggregates and within which there is habit, one will sit due to the cause and condition of the pain of birth and death;

The middling fine, soft sensations obtained by the body become the cause and condition for attachment to pain, within which there are five aggregates and within which there is habit, one will sit due to the cause and condition of the pain of birth and death;

The evil, coarse, hard, painful, and unbearable sensations that the body obtains are caused by attachment to pain. Within this there are five aggregates and within this there are habits, which will lead to the pain of birth and death caused by sitting.
The Buddha said:
The bodhisattvas have not yet become weary of the pain of birth and death caused by conditions.
The bodhisattvas said:
It is precisely because we are weary of the pain of birth and death caused by conditions that we become bodhisattvas.
The Buddha said:
You are weary of the pain of birth and death.
Why do you not plant the causes of the Way?
Why do you plant the causes of the pain of birth and death caused by conditions, which are sinful causes?
The bodhisattvas replied to the Buddha:
We are planting the causes of the Way every day.
The Buddha said:
If you are planting the causes of the Way, why do you have the pain of birth and death caused by conditions, which is one hundred and eight?
The bodhisattvas then felt ashamed, bowed their heads, and accepted and practiced it.
All the bodhisattvas bowed their heads and asked the Buddha, saying:
Although the Buddha has spoken the sutra for us, we do not understand it.
The Buddha said:
I see that you all experience one hundred and eight kinds of suffering, but I know that you do not understand.
The bodhisattvas bowed again and said:
We pray that the Buddha will explain it for us.
The Buddha said:

When a bodhisattva's mind thinks of something and wants to obtain it but cannot, at that time there is suffering, within which there are five aggregates and within which there are habits, this is called the suffering of planting.

It moves into the mind. When the mind thinks of something, thinking of what is agreeable and disagreeable is the suffering of planting, within which there are five aggregates and within which there are habits, this is called the suffering of planting.

It moves into consciousness. When consciousness cognizes something and is unable to accept it, there is suffering, within which there are five aggregates and within which there are habits, this is called the suffering of planting.ğŸ”½ It moves into the eyes. When the eyes see good forms, there is suffering, within which there are five aggregates and within which there are habits, this is called the suffering of planting;
when the eyes see middling forms, there is suffering, within which there are five aggregates and within which there are habits, this is called the suffering of planting;
The unpleasant forms seen by the eyes are painful, with five aggregates and habits in between, this is called the pain of planting.

Turning to the ears, the pleasant sounds heard by the ears are painful, with five aggregates and habits in between, this is called the pain of planting;ğŸ”½the sounds of the middle heard by the ears are painful, with five aggregates and habits in between, this is called the pain of planting;
the unpleasant sounds heard by the ears are painful, with five aggregates and habits in between, this is called the pain of planting.

Turning to the nose, the pleasant fragrances smelled by the nose are painful, with five aggregates and habits in between, this is called the pain of planting;ğŸ”½the middle fragrances smelled by the nose are painful, with five aggregates and habits in between, this is called the pain of planting;
the unpleasant foul smells smelled by the nose are painful, with five aggregates and habits in between, this is called the pain of planting.

Transference to the mouth: delicious flavors and pleasant words experienced by the mouth are painful, with five aggregates and habits therein, this is called the pain of planting;ğŸ”½middling flavors and middling words experienced by the mouth are painful, with five aggregates and habits therein, this is called the pain of planting;
unpleasant flavors and unpleasant words experienced by the mouth are painful, with five aggregates and habits therein, this is called the pain of planting.
Transference to the body: fine, smooth, and pleasant sensations experienced by the body are painful, with five aggregates and habits therein, this is called the pain of planting;
middling fine, smooth sensations experienced by the body are painful, with five aggregates and habits therein, this is called the pain of planting;
unpleasant, coarse, rough, painful, and unpleasant sensations experienced by the body are painful, with five aggregates and habits therein, this is called the pain of planting.
The Buddha said:

Bodhisattvas who have severed these one hundred and eight pains may be called bodhisattvas in practice, those who have not severed pain should not be called bodhisattvas in practice. These are the ten considerations for bodhisattvas.
The Buddha said:
The bodhisattvas are still not enlightened in this way, they should consider further.
The bodhisattvas asked the Buddha:
What should we consider further?
The Buddha said:
Bodhisattvas should consider the one hundred and eight aspects of birth.
The bodhisattvas asked the Buddha:
What are the one hundred and eight aspects of birth?
The Buddha said:
When the mind of a bodhisattva is penetrated by pain, pleasure, thought, birth and death, and consciousness, there are five aggregates and habits within, which is called penetration and birth.
The Buddha said:
If the mind is guarded and not allowed to enter pain, pleasure, thought, birth and death, and consciousness, then there are no five aggregates and no habits.
The Buddha said:
Guarding the five aggregates and habits so that the mind does not move is to sever the pain of birth and death.

The connection is to connect earth, water, fire, wind, space, pain, itching, thought, life and death, and consciousness. Within there are five aggregates and within there are habits. This is called connection to birth;
When the mind is connected, it does not move.
It does not accept earth, water, fire, wind, space, pain, itching, thought, life and death, and consciousness.
Within there are five aggregates and within there are habits. This is called connection to birth;

When the mind is connected, it does not move. It does not accept earth, water, fire, wind, space, pain, itching, thought, life and death, and consciousness. It does not accept the habits of the five aggregates.
Those who are not connected fall into sin, while those whose minds do not move when connected fall into the Way. This is called connection to birth.

It turns into consciousness. Consciousness also connects earth, water, fire, wind, space, form, pain, itching, thought, life and death, and consciousness. There are then habits of the five aggregates, and it connects to life and death.
Those who are not connected fall into the pain of life and death, while those who are connected fall into the Way and do not have life and death.

Turning to the eyes, the eyes perceive good forms, within which there are five aggregates and within which there are habits, which are called piercing through birth and death. Those who block and do not move fall into the Way, while those who do not block fall into offenses;

the eyes perceive middling forms, within which there are five aggregates and within which there are habits, which are called piercing through birth and death. Those who block and do not move fall into the Way, while those who do not block fall into offenses;

The Buddha said:
The essence of bodhisattva practice is to make the mind unmoving. Moving means not yet understanding.
The bodhisattvas replied to the Buddha:
We should sit in meditation to make the mind unmoving.
The Buddha asked the bodhisattvas:
Does the mind move again after meditation?
The bodhisattvas replied to the Buddha:
The mind moves again after meditation.
The Buddha asked the bodhisattvas:
Why does it move again?
The bodhisattvas said:
It moves by itself.
The Buddha asked the bodhisattvas:
Why does it move by itself?
The bodhisattvas said:
We do not understand. We do not know why it moves.
The Buddha said:
In this way, the bodhisattvas have not yet understood.
The bodhisattvas said:
We wish that the Buddha would explain it again for us.
The Buddha said:
The reason why the bodhisattvas' meditation naturally moves and awakens is because the bodhisattvas have one hundred and eight entanglements that arise, moving and not ceasing.
The Buddha spoke like this, and all the bodhisattvas bowed their heads and accepted the teaching.
The Buddha said:
The bodhisattvas are still not yet enlightened in this way.
The bodhisattvas said:
Why is it that we are still not enlightened?
The Buddha said:
It is only because the bodhisattvas have a basis, and they do not cease to guard the one hundred and eight practices.
All the bodhisattvas bowed their heads and said:
We pray that the Buddha will explain it for us again.

Now, according to the Mingdu Sutra, the two versions here both mistakenly take this as the inverted mouth, with the many obtained flavors, middling language, up to the incomplete characteristics being unequal by themselves, a total of twenty-seven lines with three hundred and seventy-nine characters, advancing and writing them below the five aggregates, and then taking the below the five aggregates, practicing, saying by oneself I have no offenses, up to this is called the inverted mouth, a total of twenty-seven lines with three hundred and seventy-six characters, retreating and writing them below the incomplete characteristics being unequal by themselves, causing the text of the three sections to be abruptly cut off with the meaning completely lost.
Now, relying on the Mingdu Sutra to advance and retreat and correct it, and also for those who read the old Xiang and Song editions, I briefly record the correct text on the left:

In the middle, there are five aggregates. In the middle, there is a statement of habitual tendencies. One says, I have no faults. Up to this is called upside-down speech. One says, I obtain the middle flavor in the middle speech. Up to those whose characteristics are not complete, one does not say oneself that one can attain Buddhahood. How can one cause others to attain Buddhahood? And so on.
